importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the latest update in the article, indicating current developments in the Trump-Putin-Zelensky diplomatic discussions regarding Tomahawk missile deployment to Ukraine.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period immediately preceding and including the White House meeting between Trump and Zelensky, during which tensions over Tomahawk missile deployment were heightened, particularly following Putin's call with Trump.

keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump did not rule out sending Tomahawk cruise missiles to Ukraine during a call with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
Trump is not expected to commit to providing Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine in his meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, though the possibility remains open.
The US administration has prepared plans to provide the missiles if Trump decides to act, indicating flexibility and readiness for military escalation.
Zelensky and his aides view the Tomahawks as a potential game-changer, capable of compelling Putin to return to negotiations.
Putin opposed the idea, arguing that the missiles would damage the US-Russian relationship and threaten major Russian cities, though he did not believe they would impact the battlefield.
Trump’s threat of sending Tomahawks is framed as a strategic leverage tool to pressure Russia into diplomacy, not necessarily as an immediate military move.
The possibility of a peace agreement remains uncertain, with some suggesting that Trump’s diplomatic efforts in the Middle East may influence his approach to Ukraine.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central figure in the discussion of sending Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine and has maintained the possibility of such action, showing strategic flexibility in foreign policy.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is directly involved in negotiations with Trump and opposes the idea of U.S. missile deployment to Ukraine, fearing escalation and damage to bilateral relations.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelensky
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is advocating for the use of Tomahawk missiles as a deterrent to pressure Russia into peace negotiations, highlighting the strategic importance of the weapons for Ukraine.

namedEntities.name: Tomahawk cruise missiles
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These missiles are central to the geopolitical tension between the U.S. and Russia, as their potential deployment could shift the balance of power and influence the outcome of the Ukraine war.

namedEntities.name: Alaska
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The site of a prior Trump-Putin meeting two months ago, where initial discussions on peace and missile deployment began.

namedEntities.name: Budapest
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Proposed meeting location between Trump and Putin following a call, intended to potentially resolve tensions and delay further escalation.

namedEntities.name: Middle East
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump’s recent diplomatic successes in the Middle East are cited as influencing his broader approach to ending the Ukraine war through diplomacy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has not ruled out sending long-range Tomahawk cruise missiles to Ukraine, despite a recent call with Russian President Vladimir Putin, who rejected the idea and warned it would damage U.S.-Russia relations. While Trump is not expected to commit to the deployment during a scheduled meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, officials say the U.S. has prepared contingency plans. Zelensky sees the missiles as a critical tool to pressure Russia into negotiations, while Putin argues they would not change the battlefield but could destabilize diplomatic ties. The potential for escalation remains a concern, though some officials maintain that previous escalatory actions have not significantly worsened the conflict. A planned meeting between Trump and Putin in Budapest may buy Moscow more time as Trump shifts toward diplomatic solutions, influenced by recent success in Middle East diplomacy.
title: Trump hasn’t closed the door on sending Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine
